The deadline for paper submissions is 20th February. We would like to encourage you all to submit a paper or panel proposal and take part in the conference. [...] Nicola Pratt 2015-02-02T10:15:06+00:00 2015-02-02T10:15:06+00:00 Fw: Any interest in a MESA Panel?? https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=LSEMEC;c1158326.1502 Following up on John's request, could I remind you to renew your MESA membership before 9 February so that you are eligible to vote in the current referendum on the motion condemning attacks on individuals and organizations who have chosen to endorse BDS and to \ufffd\ufffdfacilitate discussion of BDS within MESA over the coming year? The referendum closes on 9 February. \ufffd\ufffd more details here:\ufffd\ufffdReferendum Ballot on 2014 Resolution<br>| \ufffd\ufffd |<br>| \ufffd\ufffd | \ufffd\ufffd | \ufffd\ufffd | \ufffd\ufffd | \ufffd\ufffd | |<br>| Referendum Ballot on 2014 Resolution Referendum Ballot on 2014 Resolution | |<br>| | |<br> [...] John Chalcraft 2015-01-30T11:51:45+00:00 2015-01-30T11:51:45+00:00 Any interest in a MESA Panel?? https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=LSEMEC;1184bf04.1501 Dear Colleagues,<br><br>I am hoping to put together a panel for the Annual Meeting of MESA in Denver, CO in November 2015 http://mesana.org/annual-meeting/call-for-papers.html . The deadline for panel submission is 12 February. I am pasting in a tentative blurb for the panel below. Do please let me know if you might be interested in joining me. I was thinking of presenting myself on the similarities between the BDS movement for Palestinian rights and recent forms of radically democratic and horizontalist activism. [...] John Chalcraft 2015-01-16T14:05:04+00:00 2015-01-16T14:05:04+00:00 Theorising Revolution, Anticipating Civil War in 1960s Lebanon https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=LSEMEC;6ccd136e.1501 From: LSE Middle East Centre [mailto:mec.events=lse.ac.uk@mail28.atl71.mcdlv.net] On Behalf Of Mec.Events Sent: 15 January 2015 12:38 To: Chalcraft,JT Subject: Theorising Revolution, Anticipating Civil War in 1960s Lebanon Dr Fadi Bardawil View this email in your browser<http://us2.campaign-archive1.com/?u=3d36dd6f1efd9e75e763f1bb9&id=fb160115cd&e=f914bac0b6> <http://lse.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=3d36dd6f1efd9e75e763f1bb9&id=63ea388a4c&e=f914bac0b6>[https://gallery.mailchimp.com/3d36dd6f1efd9e75e763f1bb9/images/e1658073-794f-4d00-adfe-aef3369b9d63.jpg]<http://lse.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=3d36dd6f1efd9e75e763f1bb9&id=63ea388a4c&e=f914bac0b6><http://lse.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=3d36dd6f1efd9e75e763f1bb9&id=63ea388a4c&e=f914bac0b6> Theorising Revolution, Anticipating Civil War: Class, State, and Political Practice in 1960s Lebanon [https://gallery.mailchimp.com/3d36dd6f1efd9e75e763f1bb9/images/9e4ba5da-a132-4383-9ad4-83ff5f3f45e5.jpg] Palestinian Fatah fighters in Beirut in 1979 21 January 2015 | 16.30 - 18.30 | Room 9.05, Tower 2 Speaker: Dr Fadi Bardawil In the aftermath of the June 1967 defeat of the Arab armies by Israel, the Palestinian resistance began launching guerrilla operations from southern Lebanese towns. This was [...] Toby Matthiesen 2014-12-17T22:36:24+02:00 2014-12-17T22:36:24+02:00 Migration, Minorities and Radical Networks: Labour Movements and Opposition Groups in Saudi Arabia, 1950-1975 https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=LSEMEC;9639f9af.1412 I thought this article could be of interest. List members without access to a University network can send me a email to request a pdf of the article.<br><br>Abstract:<br>This article shows how ideas of Arab nationalism, socialism, and communism spread to the Arab Gulf states. It outlines how migrant workers, teachers, students returning from abroad, and the emergence of a print culture filled with Arab nationalist and leftist ideas in the 1940s created the basis for widespread political mobilization in the oil-rich Eastern Province of Saudi Arabia. After major strikes in 1953 and 1956 and a harsh crackdown, leftist [...] John Chalcraft 2014-12-09T10:40:58+00:00 2014-12-09T10:40:58+00:00 Chabanet and Royall https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=LSEMEC;b46da394.1412 Herewith notice of a new title of interest:<br><br>From Silence to Protest: International Perspectives on Weakly Resourced Groups<br><br>Ashgate<br>November 2014<br><br>Edited by Didier Chabanet, Sciences Po (Cevipof) and Ecole Normale Sup\ufffd\ufffdrieure de Lyon, Lettres et Sciences Humaines (Triangle), France. 'd.Markakis@lse.ac.uk'; Strieff,DP (pgr); 'dana_rubin_dabach@yahoo.com'; 'Dyala Badran'; Shaoulian-Sopher,E (pgr); 'Elizabeth Frantz'; [...] John Chalcraft 2014-11-03T12:06:13+00:00 2014-11-03T12:06:13+00:00 Joel Beinin at LSE https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=LSEMEC;d0af6d54.1411 Dear Colleagues,<br><br>I am happy to announce that Joel Beinin is appearing twice at LSE this week as part of the Social Movements and Popular Mobilisation in the MENA Lecture and Seminar Series.<br><br>On Tuesday he will be giving a public lecture "High-Risk Activism and Popular Struggle against the Israeli Occupation of the West Bank"<br>Speaker: Professor Joel Beinin, Stanford University<br>Chair: Dr John Chalcraft, LSE<br>Date: Tuesday 4 November 2014<br>Time: 18.30-20.00<br>Location: Wolfson Theatre, New Academic Building, LSE<http://www.lse.ac.uk/mapsanddirections/findingyourwayaroundlse.aspx>|<br>Event Hashtag: #LSEBeinin [...] Frederic Volpi 2014-07-19T14:29:39+00:00 2014-07-19T14:29:39+00:00 Re: Kurzman https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=LSEMEC;ae0f143.1407 Will keep you posted on development with MESA.<br><br>Agreed about the 'grand' theory point. But of course, not all meta debates are worth debating...<br><br>Frederic John Chalcraft 2014-07-18T09:02:19+00:00 2014-07-18T09:02:19+00:00 Re: Kurzman https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=LSEMEC;c5761af1.1407 Frederic,<br>Thanks for this!<br>It would be terrific indeed to have those papers circulated. We'd all appreciate that.<br>The more structural approach may well be linked to the scale of the analysis - but this implies that there is a method for one empirical scale / situation and a method for another kind of situation - which I'm sure can be a very helpful heuristic device - but I suspect is a logic that Dobry rejects. Such a method - what political scientists in my department call a 'domain restriction' - is only satisfactory if one gives up on the [...] Frederic Volpi 2014-07-17T16:24:48+00:00 2014-07-17T16:24:48+00:00 Re: Kurzman https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=LSEMEC;542aa667.1407 Yes indeed, there are many interesting similarities between Dobry and Kurzman. (Although Dobry seems to dismiss the kind of approach advocated by Kurzman in the paper that you posted as one of the likely fallacies.)<br>I suspect Dobry's more structuralist approach is linked to the scale of the analysis ...Dobry reflects on the entire social field, whereas Kurzman is more situational.<br>It may be of interest to the list members to have access to the conference papers that Kurzman et al are preparing for our MESA roundtable. If so I could ask them if it would be ok to circulate [...] John Chalcraft 2014-07-17T07:33:35+00:00 2014-07-17T07:33:35+00:00 Re: Fillieule & Bennani-Chraibi https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=LSEMEC;cba5129.1407 Very useful thanks very much posting that. I'm hoping we'll get more such posts on the list. There are also these affinities between Dobry and Kurzman. Although Dobry tells me that he came first!! (There's his book from the 1980s - only in French). Dobry seems to keep hold of the structure somehow, however, whereas Kurzman does not - or is that too crude?<br>All best,<br>John [...] Frederic Volpi 2014-07-16T19:23:54+00:00 2014-07-16T19:23:54+00:00 Re: Fillieule & Bennani-Chraibi https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=LSEMEC;c1f0113e.1407 Thanks for this John.<br>Yes Dobry is very interesting in this respect. Unfortunately not much of what he does (including his main book on the sociology of political crises) is published in English.<br>Someone else who makes good use of Dobry's approach and who publishes more often in English is Olivier Fillieule. His 2012 article on the sociology of revolutionary situations that addresses directly the Arab uprisings is quite interesting. It is in the 'revue francaise de science politique' 62/5; and they have an English translation of the journal (albeit not a very good one).<br>In case it is of [...] John Chalcraft 2014-07-14T12:25:35+00:00 2014-07-14T12:25:35+00:00 Dobry - political fluidity https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=LSEMEC;e41c9a34.1407 Colleagues,<br>This looks very interesting to me - especially re how to analyse revolutionary situations, how to connect micro and macro, and how to do justice to creative forms without throwing structure out of the window. If anyone knows related references - I'd be very grateful.<br>All good wishes,<br>John<br><br>Dr J. T. Chalcraft<br>Associate Professor in the History and Politics of Empire / Imperialism<br>Department of Government<br>London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE)<br>Houghton St, London<br>WC2A 2AE [...] John Chalcraft 2014-06-26T20:55:17+00:00 2014-06-26T20:55:17+00:00 International workshop: New agendas in critical and radical history, Amsterdam Dec 11-12. https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=LSEMEC;85643a3d.1407 This could well be interesting to those on this Listserve. All good wishes, John International workshop: New agendas in critical and radical history At least in Western-Europe and the US, radical approaches to history writing have long held a position in the margins of the field. This has been true since the decline in popularity of \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdcritical theory\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdhistory from below\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd associated with the new social movements of the 1960s and 1970s. But there are signs of a revival. This has been true since the decline in popularity of \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdcritical theory\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdhistory from below\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd associated with the new social movements of the 1960s and 1970s. The global financial crisis that started in 2008 prompted new interest in the long history of capitalism, often intended to [...] Sara Masry 2014-06-03T13:01:30+00:00 2014-06-03T13:01:30+00:00 EVENT TODAY: What Future for Pan-Arabism? The Case of Egypt https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=LSEMEC;6c1f7f6e.1406 Dear all,<br><br>In case of interest, please find details below regarding an event today on the future of pan-Arabism, coordinated by LSE's Ralph Miliband Programme and to be chaired by its convenor, Dr Robin Archer.<br><br>Kind regards,<br><br>Sara<br><br>What Future for Pan-Arabism? The Case of Egypt<br><br>Date: Tuesday 3 June 2014<br>Time: 6.30-8pm<br>Venue: New Theatre, East Building<br>Speaker: Dr Reem Abou-El-Fadl<br>Chair: Dr Robin Archer [...] Sara Masry 2014-06-02T14:27:46+00:00 2014-06-02T14:27:46+00:00 Podcast: Charles Anderson - Will the Real Palestinian Peasantry Please Sit Down? https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=LSEMEC;1cdc9049.1406 Dear all,<br><br>Please find below the podcast from Dr Charles Anderson's seminar here at LSE on 20 May as part of the Social Movements and Popular Mobilisation in the MENA research theme, speaking on the Palestinian peasantry in the period 1917-1936 of British rule in Palestine.<br><br>http://www.lse.ac.uk/middleEastCentre/Events/events2014/CA-20-05-14.aspx<br><br>Kind regards,<br><br>Sara<br><br>From: Masry,S<br>Sent: 15 May 2014 13:40<br>To: Masry,S; LSEMEC@JISCMAIL.AC.UK<br>Subject: CORRECTION - Dr Maha Abdelrahman's Podcast [...]
